title: 107_hr4803
content: The Act may be cited as the "Right of Passage Community Service Act". During the teenage years, young people's choices can impact their future. How they spend this time can lead to active citizenship or risky behavior. Research shows that helping others can empower youth to improve their own lives. With proper training, teenagers can make a significant contribution to their communities, making volunteer service a potential rite of passage for future generations. The National Academy of Sciences Report on Youth Development emphasizes the importance of raising skilled and responsible adults for the country's future well-being. The purpose of the Act is to create a national network of service programs for middle school students to serve in their communities, participate in leadership development workshops, and reinforce their connection to the community. The Act aims to create service programs for middle school students to serve in their communities, participate in leadership workshops, and instill an ethic of service in young people for life. The Act establishes a Right of Passage Community Service Program for middle school students to engage in community service and leadership workshops. The National and Community Service Act of 1990 is amended to include a community-based Right of Passage after school and summer service corps program for young people. This program offers opportunities for community service, leadership development, public speaking, conflict resolution, team building, and academic goals linked to service-learning curricula. Older AmeriCorps members will organize service projects and mentor participants. The National and Community Service Act of 1990 is amended to include a Right of Passage program for young people aged 12 to 16, offering community service, leadership development, and academic goals. Older AmeriCorps members will organize service projects and mentor participants. The National and Community Service Act of 1990 includes a Right of Passage program for young people aged 12 to 16, offering community service, leadership development, and academic goals. Participants must commit to at least 160 hours of service over 2 months to 1 year and will receive an educational award upon completion. Participants who complete 160 hours of service in the Right of Passage program will receive a $500 education award. Amendments to Section 146 now include eligibility for programs described in section 122(a)(15). The Corporation will submit a report to Congress within 3 years of the Act's enactment, evaluating the program authorized by the Act.
